articles.title: Rainbow lorikeet is our most commonly spotted bird, Australia's largest citizen science event finds
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Some 57,000 people participated in the Aussie Bird Count. The lorikeet joined the miner and magpie in the top three spots, followed by the noisy miner and the noisy magpie. The rainbow loriket is the most colourful bird in Australia.

articles.title: Maine Sen. Angus King fumes at removal of climate change from U.S. threat assessment
articles.author: Chris D’Angelo
articles.summary: Maine has been described as a 'climate haven' but the Pine Tree State is feeling the effects of climate change. The 2025 threat assessment released by the Trump administration does not mention climate change in its annual reports on national security threats. Sen. Angus King asked Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard about the sudden change.

articles.title: Sen. Angus King fumes at removal of climate change from US threat assessment
articles.author: Chris D Angelo
articles.summary: Maine has been described as a 'climate haven' but the Pine Tree State is feeling the effects of climate change. Sea levels here are forecast to rise approximately 4 feet by the end of the century, forcing coastal communities, shipyards and military installations to prepare and adapt. For more than a decade, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence included climate change in its annual reports on global and regional threats to U.S. national security. The 2025 threat assessment, released on March 18, does not mention climate change or other environmental threats.

There is a decline in volunteer firefighters, which undermines Australia's capacity to combat the rampant bushfires linked to climate change.

articles.author: Jesse Kearse
articles.summary: Rising seas are already affecting coastal communities in Aotearoa New Zealand. Some parts of New Zealand's coastline are also sinking. In many New Zealand cities, shorelines are steadily subsiding, with growing impacts on coastal infrastructure. New satellite measurements provide a detailed picture of urban subsidence.

articles.author: Arab News
articles.summary: David Archer is one of the world's leading climatologists. He predicts that if we continue to emit carbon dioxide we may eventually cancel the next ice age and raise the oceans by 50 meters. The human-driven, planet-wide thaw has already begun and will continue to impact Earth's climate for hundreds of thousands of years.

articles.title: Regional Climate Collaborative Posts 5-Year Impact Report
articles.author: Kelsey Buttitta
articles.summary: The Santa Barbara County Regional Climate Collaborative (SBCRCC) is celebrating its 5th Anniversary with the release of its 5-Year Impact Report. The SBCR CC was formed on March 13, 2020 as an open, voluntary network by the county, UCSB, cities and nonprofits to address the region's climate challenges. Since 2020, the collaborative has expanded and diversified its membership and work across the county by securing some $3.5 million in grants to launch regional initiatives. The Collaborative has 60 member organizations and 110 individuals.

articles.title: New Zealand's climate credibility is going down the plughole
articles.summary: It's the 10th anniversary of the Paris Climate Change Agreement. 192 countries committed to the task of keeping the rate of global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels by 2050. New Zealand's contribution to the Paris Agreement was to reduce emissions by 50% by 2030. The government submitted its plan for the next 10 years on January 30 this year. It's taking the enormous step of reducing emissions by an extra 1% to 51%.

articles.title: St. Kitts and Nevis and Nigeria strengthen sgribusiness ties
articles.author: BI Africa

The Summit sought to open new avenues for collaboration between Nigeria and the twin-island, particularly in the realm of food security and agribusiness. Both nations share common challenges in ensuring food security in the face of climate change, grappling with the impacts of rising temperatures and erratic weather patterns on agricultural productivity. Nevisian Premier Mark Brantley addressed the need to diversify macroeconomic partnerships.

These large cities along the Atlantic have not built major barriers to hurricane-driven floods, and the costs would be billions.

Instead, they're pivoting their strategies to stay profitable on a rapidly warming Earth. articles.author: Net News Ledger Weather Desk

There's a 40% chance of snow flurries in the afternoon. It will be sunny on Monday, but still cold with a low of -2°C. On Tuesday, the region will see full sunshine and a high of +5°C starting from Tuesday. On Wednesday, the temperature will rise to 11°C under a mix of sun and cloud.

articles.title: Finland uses up annual share of natural resources
articles.author: STT
articles.summary: People in Finland have consumed their share of the Earth's natural resources by Sunday, 6 April. According to the WWF, Finland's overconsumption is driven by excessive logging, the high consumption of animal-based food and the use of fossil fuels.

articles.title: NOAA vital for RI's safety; athletic league wrong to alter gender policy
